page_analysis.text_content:
Height
&
grade

Height allowances enable a variety of architectural styles while preserving the residential scale of our neighborhoods as well as the privacy and natural light available to each lot.

Code sections
Page 46
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
Page 47
18.04.030 (64) (b)

46

Height

Structure                                Max. height
                                        to roof peak

Main dwelling on a standard lot
with a roof slope ≥12:12               30'

Main dwelling on a standard lot
with a roof slope ≥12:12               33'

Main dwelling on a substandard
or flag lot                            17'

Accessory structure in rear or
side yard                              12'

2nd-dwelling units                     17'

Fig 42 Comparison of roof slopes

33'                                    Height measured to top of roof material
30'

12 : 14    12 : 12    12 : 10    12 : 6    12 : 3

Height limit = 33'                     Height limit = 30'

Fig 43 Determining slope of roof

12"
run

6"
rise

Roof slope is the vertical rise in inches for every horizontal distance of twelve inches (called the "run"). It is expressed as rise:run or, in this example 6:12.

Note: On a drawing this slope might also be represented as:

1:2
6     or     1

2

visual_elements.description: Height specifications table showing different structure types and their maximum height to roof peak. Contains 5 rows with structure descriptions and corresponding height limits (30', 33', 17', 12', 17')
Fig 42 - Comparison of roof slopes showing 5 house silhouettes with different roof slopes (12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, 12:3) under height limits of 33' and 30'
Fig 43 - Technical diagram showing how to determine roof slope with a 12" run and 6" rise measurement, including visual representation of slope calculation

technical_specifications.parameter: Main dwelling standard lot roof slope ≥12:12
Main dwelling standard lot roof slope ≥12:12
